ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: This course helps students gain confidence with reading and interpreting scientific reports across a range of subjects. It also provides the chance to talk with very successful scientists about both their research and their larger careers. Though I was not always extremely interested in the weekly readings, I did find each class period useful for these two reasons.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The expectations for this class were very clear and also very consistent. Work was steady but relatively light.
Good chance to read broadly in the biogeochemistry literature.
Learning to talk to people in the field and see they are just individuals that are excited about what they do
I really liked having the face time with this research scientists, and thought it was interesting to be able to get a sense for how the publication process works.
Getting to know the diverse aspects of the most "trendy" current aquatic biogeochemical research

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think the course runs very smoothly--I don't really have any recommendations for improvement. Pete often started classes with a chance to summarize the purpose of the paper in one or two sentences (and each member of the group spoke). I found this helpful, because it encouraged everyone to speak. So, that could be standardized as common practice for class openings.
Posting materials a bit earlier

In some ways, I wish we had been able to discuss more of the difficult pieces of every paper and not just the general ideas. Discussion of the statistical analysis specifically would've been really helpful. Sometimes I felt like even after a Monday class, I didn't really understood the paper any better.

1. Would it be helpful to broaden the scope of materials we read, including technical reports by governmental agencies and major non-profit organizations, so that we can Skype in speakers from more diverse areas, e.g. practitioners and officials, and learn about on-the-ground projects in addition to research articles? 2. Given the limited time and number of classes we have as F&ES masters students, in the future would it be possible to merge this class with Gabe Benoit's Biogeochemistry and Pollution into a 4-credit course?

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Yes, we read a paper each week and discussed it--total alignment.
It was great.
Very effective and well organized! It'a amazing and a rare opportunity to directly speak to influential researchers in the field.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Helped provide some needed background in a topic area that relates to my research.
I would say this was useful in the sense that you get a better idea of how to read scientific papers and how to begin to talk to scientists about the work that they're doing.
I study biogeochemistry. This is central to my academic interest at FES.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I took this course because I wanted Marva fluency and how to read scientific papers and some of the thought process behind biogeochemical research.
Same as above

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes! I am significantly more comfortable approaching papers that are out of my normal subject matter or comfort zone as a result of this course.
It exceeded my expectations. Reading papers actually provided a coherent teaching experience thanks to petes selection
Yes, in fact I think in some aspects, the course really exceeded my expectations. The guest speakers were really fantastic!
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's a good choice! The workload is very manageable, and the papers selected are always interesting for different reasons. This course is definitely what you make of it. I'd suggest it for people looking to gain experience and comfort across a range of biogeochemistry topics.

If you're interested in being at the nexus of policy and science, it's a really great way to understand how science works in the research realm. Check the scheduled speakers and look at their CVs and see if their career paths interest you, because it's a really great way to get to know them, and feel more connected in that space. You don't need to have a lot of biogeochemical understanding to get a lot out of this course.
Read the assigned materials in advance and in detail. Come prepared.
